items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers isÂ adamant that his budget willÂ not make inflation worse and force the Reserve Bank's hand on interest rates â€” but economists are divided.

title.children: What does the federal budget mean for inflation and interest rates?

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit, tie and glasses, stands and smiles. Blurred tree branches in the background.

items.synopsis: What do you need to know about this year's federal budget?Â We're putting your questions to experts from around ABC News. Follow live for theÂ answers.

title.children: What's in the budget for pensioners? And your other questions answered

schema.headline: Federal budget 2023 live: Albanese defends Jobseeker increase after budget revealed, as ABC News examines how it affects you

liveBlogUpdate.headline: NSW a big beneficiary of 'green' money in the budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's more from data journalist Catherine Hanrahan in New South Wales. The federal government have allocated $12 billion in the budget to rewire the nation to build an 82 per cent renewable grid by 2030. NSW will collect $4.7 billion of that funding to unlock transmission and Renewable Energy Zones in partnership with the NSW government. The state is also expected to be a beneficiary of the $2 billion allocated to the Hydrogen Headstart program, which the Albanese government says will ensure Australia becomes a renewable energy superpower. NSW has three hydrogen hubs in the Illawarra, Hunter and Wagga Wagga regions.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Northern Territory budget spends big on roads and housing
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Matt Garrick As Australia digests all the news from the federal budget, the Northern Territory is simultaneously sinking its teeth into its own budget papers, which also rolled out on Tuesday. NT Treasurer Eva Lawlerâ€™s inaugural budget features a massive infrastructure spend planned for the impending financial year, with $2.1 billion pegged mainly for the jurisdictionâ€™s roads and housing. While the construction and mining sectors have applauded this yearâ€™s allocations, thereâ€™s not been any huge departmental increases put on the table for health, education or the NT Police force. The NT opposition, police union and territoryâ€™s social services council have all criticised the 2023 NT budget's priorities, saying more focus should've been placed on the region's most vulnerable. Opposition Leader Lia Finocchiaro said police were all but ignored in the middle of a "crime crisis".

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for the ABC?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: What is in the  Budget for the ABC? - Shane. Hi Shane, thanks for your question. We put it to political reporter Jake Evans: Hi Shane, this federal budget provided an additional $52.4 million over three years for the ABC and an additional $45 million over four years for the SBS, on top of $7.7 billion going to both national broadcasters over the next five years. Those additional payments are described as being for the ABC to continue to support local news and current affairs services, and for the SBS to continue to make news content available for Chinese and Arabic speaking communities in Australia.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Watch: Dutton says budget surplus is courtesy of previous government
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The opposition leader commends the federal government on the budget but says it inherited a "good set of figures".

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Tenant's Union of Tasmania: rent help not a game-changer
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Alexandra Humphries The maximum rate of Rent Assistance will increase by 15 per cent, or up to $31 per fortnight from September. Ben Bartl is the principal solicitor with the Tenant's Union of Tasmania has told The World Today any increase is welcome. "It's the biggest increase (in rent assistance) in more than three decades and it will provide cost of living relief for many Tasmanians," he said. But Mr Bartl says they won't fix a broken system. "It shouldn't be forgotten that rents across Tasmania have increased by $75 a week over the last two years. So while the increase (to assistance) will provide some cost of living relief, it doesn't go far enough."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Independent MP says the budget could have 'gone further' on climate
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Lara Corrigan and Wing Kuang Independent MP Allegra Spender said while the latest federal budget is "a pretty positive budget for climate", she believed it could have gone further. Spender also told ABC NewsRadio that she didn't think the additional $2.4 billion Petroleum Rent Resources Tax (PRRT), which is subjected to gas and oil companies, was "enough". "I think the PRRT reforms were a missed opportunity," she said. "Australia is unique in our resources and we need to make sure that the Australian taxpayers get the benefit from that." Spender also thought the household electrification incentives, which was to help Australians to move away from relying on gas, was "just a first step" to help reduce emissions and cost of living. "I think we need to go further, particularly in terms of giving households the tools and information to make some of this transition," she said. "Because it's not only money, it's also a tricky transition sometimes."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Question: Any incentive in the budget to pay HECS-HELP sooner?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Is there any incentive in the budget regarding paying hecs/help sooner. Eg There used to be the 10% discount - Steve. Hi Steve, thanks for your question. I've passed it to political reporter Jake Evans who says: There's a big "TBC" over the whole higher education sector, because the government is currently in negotiations with unions, universities and others to develop a "University Accord". That deal would be very wide-ranging, looking not only at tertiary education funding and structure, but also at student loans and loan repayment. For now, there's no new incentive schemes or loan relief, besides a technical decision by the government to forgo $21 million worth of debt it would be owed over the next decade from loans issued in 2017 and 2018 under the VET FEE-HELP program, due to delays in the transfer of those loans to the Australian Taxation Office. It means students currently paying off loans face a 7 per cent increase on June 1 when they are indexed, which will add thousands more to many student debts.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Energy consumers to see less severe hikes
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Rachel Mealey Energy Consumers Australia says the subsidies announced for energy bills will hold back price rises. Chief executive Lynne Gallagher told The World Today the 36 percent prise-rise forecast in the October budget will now be lower. "I think what the government's really saying is that the measures that they brought in December have brought down coal and gas prices which are bringing down wholesale prices," she said. "And then if you factor in the additional money in this budget that's being matched by the states, if you take that into account, then what consumers will see is only a 10 per cent increase in their bill."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: University student considers moving back home as costs skyrocket
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Huw Morrisson is in his first year studying a science degree after spending some time working in nursing. He hopes to get into the wildlife biology space, but at the moment he's struggling to make ends meet, spending about half his weekly income on rent in his Brisbane share house. As the cost of living continues to soar, he's considering moving back in with his parents as he'll struggle to afford rising rental costs. " It's been real tough. Prices are going up for just about everything. Rent is also going up," he told News Breakfast. He's currently looking for casual work in nursing to supplement his income. He's receiving Centrelink payments, but it's not enough to cover the basics. "I don't have the money for new tyres, so I just have to not drive [my car], basically. It just sits here."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What people in need think about the federal budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Kirsty Parkes, the founder of Community Cafe, suggests the government do more with the surplus to provide relief for people in need.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Questions from you: Any support for long COVID in the budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Is there any support for Long COVID management in the budget? - Bluey. Hi Bluey ðŸ‘€ Thanks for writing in. I've put your question to political reporter Jake Evan s who says: There is no new money for long COVID management in this budget. However the federal government has committed $50 million for further research on long COVID to be paid through the Medical Research Future Fund. A parliamentary committee inquiry into long COVID and repeat infections was released just at the end of last month, which included recommendations for long COVID clinics to be established in some public hospitals, more support and education. The government is developing its national plan on long COVID which it says will consider the findings of that committee's inquiry, so we may see more on this in the future.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Western Sydney GP says bulk-billing incentive an 'important stop-gap' measure
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Alison Xiao for The World Today Mount Druitt-based GP Dr Kean-Seng Lim has told The World Today his patients will benefit from the government's tripling of the bulk-billing incentive payment for doctors. "In an outer Metro practice, we have a higher than average number of patients with healthcare cards, or those who are pensioners or those who are under the age of 16." "Were in a position where we were having to seriously consider charging a gap to all patients including pensioners, and cardholders, and this new measure will mean that we will now be able to continue to bulk bill, all the needy in our population."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Conservation groups say the budget doesn't do enough for the environment
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By the Specialist Reporting Team's Loretta Florance: The government came into office with a mandate to improve Australia's environmental record, but conservation groups say while the budget has some promising measures on climate change, it doesn't provide nearly enough money to back the government's ambitious agenda to do more to protect the country's natural environment. The Australian Conservation Foundation's Kelly O'Shanassy welcomes investment in "climate action, renewable energy and clean exports", including $2 billion to speed up development of Australia's hydrogen industry and $1.3 billion towards energy efficiency in houses. "That's really important because Australians are struggling with the cost of living and investing in energy efficiency in homes," she says. There was also $121 million over four years to make good on the government's promise to set up a new national body, Environment Protection Australia (EPA), as well as another $51.5 million over four years for a new environment information agency. Ms O'Shanassy says that's "a good investment in forming a new agency". But the public is yet to see legislation to establish a national EPA, and the Wilderness Society's Tim Beshara says the government needs to get on with it. "The new EPA and a data collection agency is a good start for figuring out how we do address the problems that we're facing on the nature side," he says. "[But] I think that's a patch-up for where we should have been. I think that should have been in last year's budget and we should have been well advanced from where we're at right now to the reform agenda." Both groups also say the government hasn't put any significant new money behind its ambitious goal of zero extinctions. "There's nothing in this budget that is going to lead to additional species coming off the [endangered] list in the right way â€” that is not becoming extinct, but actually becoming more and more common, less and less rare," Beshara says. "The Australian government has obligations for hundreds of species to have put in place a recovery plan and to fund that, and the backlog on writing those plans and implementing those plans and funding those plans is rising. "So, until there is dedicated additional substantive funding put into endangered species recovery, things are going to continue to decline. It's hard not to see we're going to have more extinctions [under] the Albanese government."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Questions from you: Who is eligible for energy bill relief?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Is there any information about the eligibility criteria for the $500 energy relief? Everywhere I read it says there will be a $500 relief for energy bills for eligible households but no information as to who is eligible. - John. Hi John. Here's the lowdown from political reporter, Jake Evans: The energy relief payment will be available to pensioners, veterans, seniors and other concession card holders, as well as recipients of Carer Allowance, Family Tax Benefit and anyone eligible for existing state and territory electricity concession schemes. However, the amount you receive will differ from state to state, as the money is jointly funded and the federal government has had to strike eight different deals with each state and territory. $500 will be offered in NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania $350 in total relief will be available in Western Australia and the territories $650 will also be available to eligible small businesses in states that have matched the relief.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Daniel Andrews takes a shot at previous governments in budget reaction
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Tim Callanan Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has taken a swipe at previous Liberal federal governments in his reaction to last night's federal budget. Andrews said there were positive signs in the budget for Victoria, declaring "the decade of rip off is over." "You canâ€™t fix nine years of neglect in just one budget but there are good positive signs, but weâ€™ll keep the pressure on, of course, because we want to get our fair share," he said. Mr Andrews said the health initiatives announced last night were "a good first step" in improving medical care across the country. "National Cabinet agreed earlier this year that health is the number one issue and it was very pleasing to see significant investments â€“ not everything â€“ but a big next step in last nightâ€™s federal budget. "Particularly, longer consultations, higher payments to GPs and higher rebates particularly for vulnerable people. This is all about a better primary care system." Andrews said he would discuss more moves to reform the health system at a health-only National Cabinet meeting before the end of the year. There was no money allocated last night towards the 2026 Commonwealth Games, which Victoria is hosting in regional centres, but the Premier said that doesnâ€™t mean there wonâ€™t be a federal contribution. "The Commonwealth Games is not happening next week so we do have time and we do have some optimism that the Albanese government will be a partner," he said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What happened to those free teaching degrees?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I am curious as to what happened to the free teaching degrees for high achievers that were promised at the election. My daughter did her bit is the government going to step up? - Richard. Hi Richard, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to political reporter Jake Evans who says: We still don't have details on the future of that policy or much at all of the tertiary sector, because the federal government is still reviewing the higher education sector, with a plan to introduce a "University Accord" by the end of the year. There were no new measures for universties this budget â€” but expect more to come in the future.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Greens leader criticises JobSeeker boost payment
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Greens leader Adam Bandt says the governmentâ€™s decision to boost the JobSeeker rate for all recipients by $40 a fortnight is inadequate.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for pensioners?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A number of cost-of-living measures announced in yesterday's budget will apply to pensioners. More than 5 million households will have up to $500 deducted from their power bills in the next financial year. This will apply to pensioners, Commonwealth Seniors Health Card holders, Family Tax Benefit A and B recipients and small business customers of electricity retailers. The government is also increasing the Medicare levy low-income thresholds for singles, families and seniors and pensioners from July 1, 2022, which means more people will be exempt from paying the Medicare levy in their 2022-23 tax returns. For medicines, the budget includes a $2.2 billion increase to access for medicines through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Hey ChatGPT, is there any money in the budget for artificial intelligence?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ChatGPT has declined to comment. But here's national technology reporter, Danny Tran: Artificial intelligence is getting a boost, with the federal government tipping in $101.2 million over the next five years to help businesses integrate AI and quantum technologies. That includes expanding the National AI Centre and its role in making sure the technology is responsible (I, Robot, anyone?) as well as setting up the Australian Centre for Quantum Growth. Misha Schubert from Science and Technology Australia says this type of investment is important: "Every time anyone enters a prompt or an instruction into ChatGPT or a generative AI tool, it is hoovering that up and building a complex profile about us. "So [it is] really important that we diligently deepen our investments in ethical and responsible use of AI and the sort of safeguards around privacy and copyright and security on generative AI tools." Simon Bush from the Australian Information Industry Association, the peak body for the information and communications technology sector, says we have a "very limited" opportunity to get this technology right. "We are competing with our trading partners, both friendly and not so friendly, in relation to areas like AI and Quantum," he says. "This funding enables smaller Australian innovative companies to access government support, to commercialise their IP and their technology, to really bring that to the market and also [retain] really smart people, so [we] don't lose them overseas. "Itâ€™s a really good down payment on securing Australiaâ€™s future."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Modest cost-of-living measures 'will sadly make little difference to many'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's according to Julie Edwards from Jesuit Social Services. She says while the budget includes some positive investments to tackle the cost of living, the increase to the Jobseeker payment will do little to lift vulnerable people out of poverty. Julie: We know that many aspects of the cost of living are at near-record highs, including rental prices, petrol, groceries and other essentials, which makes it even less sustainable for a Jobseeker recipient to live a dignified life. We saw during the pandemic that increased payments reduced measures of poverty and housing stress, but a very modest increase of $2.80 per day will sadly make little difference to many. Our political leaders must create a fair social safety net that ensures all Jobseeker recipients can afford an adequate standard of living.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Nationals slams Labor for new tax on regional Australians
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Anna Pykett and Wing Kuang Nationals leader David Littleproud has slammed the federal government for introducing a new fresh food tax for farmers to cover biosecurity costs. The federal budget announced a 10 per cent increase in agricultural levies to fund biosecurity activities and organisations, expecting it to raise $153 million over three years. Littleproud told ABC NewsRadio this was an "outrageous move". "They are going to tax farmers to pay for the biosecurity costs of their competitors to import product into this country, and that has to be passed on to the consumer," he said, adding it would not help address food price inflation. He also said regional Australians would have few benefits from Labor's cost-of-living package, stressing what was needed in regional Australia was infrastructure and new childcare places. He was also concerned that new Medicare boosts would lead to the closure of regional pharmacies, meaning regional Australians might face more accessibility issues in the future. "We feel like the forgotten Australians," he said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget is 'unfair and inflationary', shadow treasurer says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has criticised Labor's spending in the budget, and said it doesn't address the root cause of inflation. The budget offers a $14.6 billion cost-of-living package, including a $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker, which the Liberal Party hasn't yet taken a position on. "Critically, in the new initiatives that Labor has brought forward there's $2 of extra spending for every $1 of revenue. And this is the critical point: That's inflationary," he told RN this morning. "What we needed was a budget that was going to take pressure off inflation, in the process then take pressure off interest rates, and of course that helps everybody. "That's why the right budget to unite Australians, to help all Australians was a budget that was going to take those pressures away." You can listen to the Shadow Treasurer's full interview on Radio National with Patricia Karvelas here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Queensland housing needs more, industry figures say
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Jemima Burt Queensland's peak social service body says the federal government needs to do more to meet the demand for housing in Queensland. This year's budget includes a significant investment in more social housing around the country, an increase to rent assistance, and concessions for build to rent projects. But Aimee McVeigh from the Queensland Council of Social Service said research shows a significant number of Queenslanders are missing out on access to affordable housing. "Our research shows that we have 300,000 Queenslanders with unmet housing needs â€¦ If we can see that federally the government is committing to 20,000 social houses across the country it is clear that the current plan bears no relationship to the need," she said. She said despite modest rises to welfare payments, there are many Queenslanders who will continue to live in poverty. "There is in this federal budget an increase of less than $3 a day for that payment. "Clearly it isn't enough to go anywhere near lifting those almost half a million Queenslanders out of poverty," Ms McVeigh said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: PM rejects claims budget could lead to further rate hikes
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The prime minister says his government has "got the balance right" and delivered a "responsible" budget.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Victorian groups welcome â€˜modestâ€™ cost of living help
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Tim Callanan Victorian social services groups have cautiously welcomed â€œmodestâ€ increases in support in the federal budget for people struggling with the cost of living crisis. That includes an increase to the JobSeeker rate by $40 a fortnight and the governmentâ€™s energy bill relief plan. Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people. â€œThere's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,â€ she said. However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be â€œtoughâ€. â€œWe've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,â€ she said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Climate Council says budget is 'a warm up lap in history's most important race'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Amanda McKenzie, CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary. McKenzie: This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower peopleâ€™s power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables. Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks. The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for WA?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By state political reporter Keane Bourke There's little in the federal budget for WA, with one of the key pledges being $11.4 million dollars to extend a defence industry training program for the state's shipbuilding sector. Extra money has also been promised for roads in Northern WA, and $16.3 million dollars for Perth to host the World Masters Games, if Australia's bid is successful. Eligible Western Australians will only receive a $350 electricity credit â€¦ below the $500 going to those along the east coast. From next year the state's GST payments will be slightly higher than forecast last year, growing to more than $9 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for infrastructure projects in NSW?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan. Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year. This time around, NSW will get $362 million over eight years, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning. There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program. The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Questions from you: What happened to the Help to Buy scheme?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. Have heard nothing on this since 21 May. Presumably it's an inflationary measure, but still a game changer for those lagging behind the housing market  - Josh. Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter Jake Evans who says: The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year. The federal government committed in that budget to $324.6 million over four years to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government. The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Does the opposition continue to support stage 3 tax cuts?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Of course we do. They have been legislated," Dutton tells News Breakfast. "We went to an election promising it, as did the prime minister. And there's about 17 broken promises now that the prime minister sits on and surely he's not going to add this one to the list as well. "I think they come in at the right time. They were staged for a reason. They haven't come in at the moment because we don't want to see that extra spending in an inflationary environment. "But I do think as you come out of the inflationary period, you do want to provide support to families who are still going to have massive electricity and gas bills to pay under Labor's policies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What about the billions to help encourage more GPs to offer bulk-billing?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We'll have more to say about that, but clearly more needs to be done in the bulk-billing space and more needs to be done in general practice and in primary care," Dutton says. "So in principle, we support more assistance to doctors to help them see patients, particularly those with acute needs and those that that require regular attendance at GPs and that includes pensioners and kids, as the government has proposed last night."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Does Dutton support the single-parent payment?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We'll have more to say about that Michael tomorrow night and some other measures as well," Dutton replies. When pressed, the opposition leader says: "Of course [single mums deserve all the help they can], and there's million families more. "Single-parent families, families with kids who are $25,000 worse off under this government and there are lots of people that deserve support because Labor has created a huge cost of living crisis and in this budget, they put upward pressure on interest rates at exactly the belong time."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Does Dutton support the JobSeeker increase?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We'll look at all of those figures and make an announcement in relation to that tomorrow night," Dutton replies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dutton calls energy-relief payments a 'short-term fix'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We support those payments to families in the way in which the government has proposed them," Dutton tells News Breakfast. "But it's a short-term fix and the problem is it's a long-term problem that they have created. "There are lots of families, millions of families, who aren't getting any assistance in this budget, who thought they were an average family with a mortgage, three children, $25,000 worse, they're worse off under Labor in this budget. That's a huge hit."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Dutton says Labor inherited 'a good set of figures'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's it for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's interview on News Breakfast. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is now taking questions from host Michael Rowland. He says the Labor government gets "a tick" for the budget being back in the black, but says it should credit the Coalition for that win. "If they had been gracious, they should acknowledge they inherited a good set of figures," Dutton says. "They obviously had a surge of income, and they have spent some of that wisely, but there's a lot of extra taxing spending that is going to be inflationary. "I worry for those families who are missing out and who are really hurting at the moment."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Voice debate having a 'difficult impact' on Indigenous Australians
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "There's money there for the referendum, which is right because we have a referendum coming up, but also $10.5 million in mental health support for Indigenous Australians in the referendum period. What does that say about the impact that this debate is having on First Nations people?" News Breakfast host Michael Rowland asks. "Well, it is having a difficult impact," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says. "There are words that are used these days on social media and in other forms often anonymous, sometimes not frankly, some of the things that are being said in this debate are hurtful. "We're very conscious of the pressure which Indigenous Australians will be under. We know that when the vote, the postal ballot was held on marriage equality, then people in that community felt under pressure as well and we have been conscious about that."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: PM pressed on difference between cost-of-living package and stage 3 tax cuts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Stage three tax cuts will cost $69 billion over four years, our cost of living package comes in at $15 billion. Can you see how some people out there â€” perhaps more than some people â€” would see a massive disconnect?" Michael Rowland asks. "Well, they, of course, were legislated some time ago. They're included in the budget as they have been for some time and we have no plans to change those measures. We haven't given consideration to that," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese replies. "Do you see how some people see $69 billion for tax cuts targeting in large part wealthy Australians compared to only $15 billion for cost of living?" Rowland repeats. "Those measures begin at $45,000. If you're on $45,000, watching this program, you don't regard yourself as being wealthy," Albanese replies.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'We got the balance right': PM responds to JobSeeker criticism
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "Independent senator David Pocock describes that as both laughable and embarrassing. Are you to offer any such a small rise in JobSeeker?" Michael Rowland asks the prime minister. "There's a great contradiction you put in the first two issues you raised with me," Anthony Albanese says. "You said we're spending too much in your first question, and the second you say we're not spending enough. The truth is we got the balance right. "We understand that people are under pressure, but we needed to make sure that it was a responsible budget so this $40 increase is something that will make a difference to people."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget 'takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation', PM says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is currently speaking to Michael Rowland on News Breakfast. Rowland : "$20 billion in new spending, is that really going to help force the inflation dragon back into its cave?" Albanese : "$40 billion of savings over two budgets, 87 per cent of the revenue gains put to the bottom line unlike our predecessors where the number was 40 per cent or the Howard government where the number was 30 per cent. This is a budget that takes pressure off families whilst not putting pressure on inflation."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How hard is it for uni students to live off Youth Allowance?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Before this year's budget, the highest rate a single, childless person on Youth Allowance could receive was around $14,600 a year â€” so how hard is it to live off the welfare payment? The ABC's Shalailah Medhora has more ðŸ‘‡

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers pressed on stage 3 tax cuts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "You revealed the cost of the stage 3 tax cuts will be $69 billion over four years, four times the cost-of-living package. What is right about that picture?" News Breakfast presenter Michael Rowland asks Treasurer Jim Chalmers. "I was asked yesterday how much they'd cost and because there's an extra year of these cuts in the forward estimates, it's a bigger number than it was last name," Chalmers said. "You can see the disparity between the figures and how that would be viewed by people. "First of all, those tax cuts kick in at $45,000 and it's important that we give back some of the bracket creep in the jargon, particularly to people on low and middle incomes, but we haven't changed our position on the stage 3 tax cuts. "What we've done in the budget last night is to provide some help for people who are doing it toughest, the most vulnerable people in our community and that shows where our priorities are. "We haven't changed our position. They don't come in for more than a year now. They haven't actually been a focus of the deliberations for this budget at all."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers explains reason for changing JobSeeker age threshold
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In case you missed it: The higher JobSeeker rate for older people, which previously applied to recipients over 60 who had received JobSeeker for 9 months or longer, will now apply for recipients over 55. It means people aged 55 to 59 will receive an additional $92.10 per fortnight above what they receive today. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says "it's a really important change." "One of the most concerning parts of the community of Australians who can't find works is over-55s and particularly women over 55 ," he told News Breakfast. "The advice that we receive from the expert committees we set up is that this is a big and growing challenge for us. It is harder and harder, particularly for women over 55, to get back into work. Big increases in homelessness and the like and we've tried to provide extra help there."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Is that JobSeeker increase the best a wealthy country can do?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: That's the question that's just been posed to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The JobSeeker base rate is increasing to $40 a fortnight, which breaks down to an extra $2.85 a day. "We've tried to do as much as we can without blowing the budget and adding substantially to inflationary pressures in the economy," Chalmers told News Breakfast. "I understand and respect that there will be people who say that we should do more. There will be people who say we shouldn't have done any of this. "We've done what we can and also a lot of people who are eligible for one of these payment increases in the budget would be eligible for two or more of these increases. "You need to look across the cost-of-living package."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Chalmers calls budget surplus a 'complex balancing act'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: "We've got this big improvement in revenues in the near term and we've taken the most responsible approach to that and that's why we're forecasting a surplus for this year," he told News Breakfast. "But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. And again, as you said before, what we've been able to do on the foundations of a much more responsible and much stronger budget is to provide help for people doing it tough at the same time as we invest in the future."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Find out if you're among the budget's winners or losers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has handed down his second budget, which looks good for the government, but what is in it for you? Have a look at this cheat sheet of what's set to receive more funding â€” and who will be paying for it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Bandt says extra JobSeeker money 'not enough to buy a loaf of bread'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Greens leader Adam Bandt says the extra $2.85 a day for JobSeeker is "not enough to buy a loaf of bread". "Labor promised no-one would be left behind. The budget leaves millions of people behind, giving tax cuts to the politicians and billionaires while every day people on Jobseeker are left in poverty," he told ABC News Breakfast. Bandt added that "5.5 million renters get absolutely nothing out of this budget". "Those lucky to get rent assistance might get a dollar a day. Rents in capital cities have been growing 10 times faster than that. "Labor doesn't understand how severe the rental and housing crisis is. People are sleeping in tents and cars. People are spending 60 per cent of their income on rents."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: $40 per fortnight for JobSeeker 'clearly not enough', ACOSS CEO says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Cassandra Goldie, the chief executive of the Australian Council of Social Service, says the $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker is "clearly not enough". "Every dollar for somebody on a very low income will make a difference but it is not enough," she told ABC News Breakfast. "We still today have a JobSeeker unemployment payment which is a poverty payment. It is one of the lowest in the OECD and we need to get it to where it should be."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Could we see another interest rate rise because of the federal budget?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is adamant his second budget will not make Australia's inflation problem worse, while providing cost of living relief â€” but economists are divided about whether that confidence is misplaced. Some economists have even suggested the budget was a "missed opportunity" for the treasurer to do more to cut inflation and put an end to rate rises by the Reserve Bank. You can continue reading this story by business reporter Kate Ainsworth below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: BCA chief says government delivered 'solid budget' but opportunities were missed
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Business Council of Australia CEO Jennifer Westacott says a budget surplus "gives confidence to markets and resilience in the future", but there were missed opportunities on multiple fronts. "The issue is it is a missed opportunity to tackle productivity and investment which will give you stronger budgets and a more sustainable surplus in the longer term," she told ABC News Breakfast. She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit. "Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this. "The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Didn't catch the budget last night? Here's what you need to know
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you weren't up frantically refreshing the blog all night (unlikely), here are a few of the key announcements you should know about: There will be $14.6 billion of cost-of-living relief, including help with power bills, reduced health costs and creating more affordable housing The government is allocating $11.3 billion to provide aged care workers with an interim increase of 15 per cent to award wages An extra $40 per fortnight will be delivered for J obSeeker, youth allowance and Austudy recipients Bulk-billing incentives will be tripled for the most common consultations with children under the age of 16, pensioners and other Commonwealth concession card holders The maximum rate of Commonwealth Rent Assistance will be increased by 15 per cent

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning!
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Welcome to today's live blog, where we'll be unpacking last night's budget. Stick with us as we bring you the latest reactions, interviews and analysis from around the ABC.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Federal budget 2023 live: Albanese defends Jobseeker increase after budget revealed, as ABC News examines how it affects you

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's more from data journalist Catherine Hanrahan in New South Wales. The federal government have allocated $12 billion in the budget to rewire the nation to build an 82 per cent renewable grid by 2030. NSW will collect $4.7 billion of that funding to unlock transmission and Renewable Energy Zones in partnership with the NSW government. The state is also expected to be a beneficiary of the $2 billion allocated to the Hydrogen Headstart program, which the Albanese government says will ensure Australia becomes a renewable energy superpower. NSW has three hydrogen hubs in the Illawarra, Hunter and Wagga Wagga regions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick As Australia digests all the news from the federal budget, the Northern Territory is simultaneously sinking its teeth into its own budget papers, which also rolled out on Tuesday. NT Treasurer Eva Lawlerâ€™s inaugural budget features a massive infrastructure spend planned for the impending financial year, with $2.1 billion pegged mainly for the jurisdictionâ€™s roads and housing. While the construction and mining sectors have applauded this yearâ€™s allocations, thereâ€™s not been any huge departmental increases put on the table for health, education or the NT Police force. The NT opposition, police union and territoryâ€™s social services council have all criticised the 2023 NT budget's priorities, saying more focus should've been placed on the region's most vulnerable. Opposition Leader Lia Finocchiaro said police were all but ignored in the middle of a "crime crisis".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What is in the  Budget for the ABC? - Shane. Hi Shane, thanks for your question. We put it to political reporter Jake Evans: Hi Shane, this federal budget provided an additional $52.4 million over three years for the ABC and an additional $45 million over four years for the SBS, on top of $7.7 billion going to both national broadcasters over the next five years. Those additional payments are described as being for the ABC to continue to support local news and current affairs services, and for the SBS to continue to make news content available for Chinese and Arabic speaking communities in Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget for the ABC?

Those additional payments are described as being for the ABC to continue to support local news and current affairs services, and for the SBS to continue to make news content available for Chinese and Arabic speaking communities in Australia.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Alexandra Humphries The maximum rate of Rent Assistance will increase by 15 per cent, or up to $31 per fortnight from September. Ben Bartl is the principal solicitor with the Tenant's Union of Tasmania has told The World Today any increase is welcome. "It's the biggest increase (in rent assistance) in more than three decades and it will provide cost of living relief for many Tasmanians," he said. But Mr Bartl says they won't fix a broken system. "It shouldn't be forgotten that rents across Tasmania have increased by $75 a week over the last two years. So while the increase (to assistance) will provide some cost of living relief, it doesn't go far enough."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tenant's Union of Tasmania: rent help not a game-changer

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Lara Corrigan and Wing Kuang Independent MP Allegra Spender said while the latest federal budget is "a pretty positive budget for climate", she believed it could have gone further. Spender also told ABC NewsRadio that she didn't think the additional $2.4 billion Petroleum Rent Resources Tax (PRRT), which is subjected to gas and oil companies, was "enough". "I think the PRRT reforms were a missed opportunity," she said. "Australia is unique in our resources and we need to make sure that the Australian taxpayers get the benefit from that." Spender also thought the household electrification incentives, which was to help Australians to move away from relying on gas, was "just a first step" to help reduce emissions and cost of living. "I think we need to go further, particularly in terms of giving households the tools and information to make some of this transition," she said. "Because it's not only money, it's also a tricky transition sometimes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Independent MP says the budget could have 'gone further' on climate

props.alt: Spender gestures while speaking.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there any incentive in the budget regarding paying hecs/help sooner. Eg There used to be the 10% discount - Steve. Hi Steve, thanks for your question. I've passed it to political reporter Jake Evans who says: There's a big "TBC" over the whole higher education sector, because the government is currently in negotiations with unions, universities and others to develop a "University Accord". That deal would be very wide-ranging, looking not only at tertiary education funding and structure, but also at student loans and loan repayment. For now, there's no new incentive schemes or loan relief, besides a technical decision by the government to forgo $21 million worth of debt it would be owed over the next decade from loans issued in 2017 and 2018 under the VET FEE-HELP program, due to delays in the transfer of those loans to the Australian Taxation Office. It means students currently paying off loans face a 7 per cent increase on June 1 when they are indexed, which will add thousands more to many student debts.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Rachel Mealey Energy Consumers Australia says the subsidies announced for energy bills will hold back price rises. Chief executive Lynne Gallagher told The World Today the 36 percent prise-rise forecast in the October budget will now be lower. "I think what the government's really saying is that the measures that they brought in December have brought down coal and gas prices which are bringing down wholesale prices," she said. "And then if you factor in the additional money in this budget that's being matched by the states, if you take that into account, then what consumers will see is only a 10 per cent increase in their bill."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy consumers to see less severe hikes

children.content: Reporting by Rachel Mealey
Energy Consumers Australia says the subsidies announced for energy bills will hold back price rises.
Chief executive Lynne Gallagher told The World Today the 36 percent prise-rise forecast in the October budget will now be lower.
"I think what the government's really saying is that the measures that they brought in December have brought down coal and gas prices which are bringing down wholesale prices," she said.

"And then if you factor in the additional money in this budget that's being matched by the states, if you take that into account, then what consumers will see is only a 10 per cent increase in their bill."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Huw Morrisson is in his first year studying a science degree after spending some time working in nursing. He hopes to get into the wildlife biology space, but at the moment he's struggling to make ends meet, spending about half his weekly income on rent in his Brisbane share house. As the cost of living continues to soar, he's considering moving back in with his parents as he'll struggle to afford rising rental costs. " It's been real tough. Prices are going up for just about everything. Rent is also going up," he told News Breakfast. He's currently looking for casual work in nursing to supplement his income. He's receiving Centrelink payments, but it's not enough to cover the basics. "I don't have the money for new tyres, so I just have to not drive [my car], basically. It just sits here."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there any support for Long COVID management in the budget? - Bluey. Hi Bluey ðŸ‘€ Thanks for writing in. I've put your question to political reporter Jake Evan s who says: There is no new money for long COVID management in this budget. However the federal government has committed $50 million for further research on long COVID to be paid through the Medical Research Future Fund. A parliamentary committee inquiry into long COVID and repeat infections was released just at the end of last month, which included recommendations for long COVID clinics to be established in some public hospitals, more support and education. The government is developing its national plan on long COVID which it says will consider the findings of that committee's inquiry, so we may see more on this in the future.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Alison Xiao for The World Today Mount Druitt-based GP Dr Kean-Seng Lim has told The World Today his patients will benefit from the government's tripling of the bulk-billing incentive payment for doctors. "In an outer Metro practice, we have a higher than average number of patients with healthcare cards, or those who are pensioners or those who are under the age of 16." "Were in a position where we were having to seriously consider charging a gap to all patients including pensioners, and cardholders, and this new measure will mean that we will now be able to continue to bulk bill, all the needy in our population."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Western Sydney GP says bulk-billing incentive an 'important stop-gap' measure

props.alt: An out of focus shot of a doctor seeing a patient.

children.content: (ABC News: Tim Swanston)
By Alison Xiao for The World Today
Mount Druitt-based GP
Dr Kean-Seng Lim
has told The World Today his patients will benefit from the government's tripling of the bulk-billing incentive payment for doctors.
"In an outer Metro practice, we have a higher than average number of patients with healthcare cards, or those who are pensioners or those who are under the age of 16."

"Were in a position where we were having to seriously consider charging a gap to all patients including pensioners, and cardholders, and this new measure will mean that we will now be able to continue to bulk bill, all the needy in our population."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By the Specialist Reporting Team's Loretta Florance: The government came into office with a mandate to improve Australia's environmental record, but conservation groups say while the budget has some promising measures on climate change, it doesn't provide nearly enough money to back the government's ambitious agenda to do more to protect the country's natural environment. The Australian Conservation Foundation's Kelly O'Shanassy welcomes investment in "climate action, renewable energy and clean exports", including $2 billion to speed up development of Australia's hydrogen industry and $1.3 billion towards energy efficiency in houses. "That's really important because Australians are struggling with the cost of living and investing in energy efficiency in homes," she says. There was also $121 million over four years to make good on the government's promise to set up a new national body, Environment Protection Australia (EPA), as well as another $51.5 million over four years for a new environment information agency. Ms O'Shanassy says that's "a good investment in forming a new agency". But the public is yet to see legislation to establish a national EPA, and the Wilderness Society's Tim Beshara says the government needs to get on with it. "The new EPA and a data collection agency is a good start for figuring out how we do address the problems that we're facing on the nature side," he says. "[But] I think that's a patch-up for where we should have been. I think that should have been in last year's budget and we should have been well advanced from where we're at right now to the reform agenda." Both groups also say the government hasn't put any significant new money behind its ambitious goal of zero extinctions. "There's nothing in this budget that is going to lead to additional species coming off the [endangered] list in the right way â€” that is not becoming extinct, but actually becoming more and more common, less and less rare," Beshara says. "The Australian government has obligations for hundreds of species to have put in place a recovery plan and to fund that, and the backlog on writing those plans and implementing those plans and funding those plans is rising. "So, until there is dedicated additional substantive funding put into endangered species recovery, things are going to continue to decline. It's hard not to see we're going to have more extinctions [under] the Albanese government."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Conservation groups say the budget doesn't do enough for the environment

children.content: By the Specialist Reporting Team's Loretta Florance:

The government came into office with a mandate to improve Australia's environmental record, but conservation groups say while the budget has some promising measures on climate change, it doesn't provide nearly enough money to back the government's ambitious agenda to do more to protect the country's natural environment.

The Australian Conservation Foundation's Kelly O'Shanassy welcomes investment in "climate action, renewable energy and clean exports", including $2 billion to speed up development of Australia's hydrogen industry and $1.3 billion towards energy efficiency in houses.
"That's really important because Australians are struggling with the cost of living and investing in energy efficiency in homes," she says.
There was also $121 million over four years to make good on the government's promise
to set up a new national body, Environment Protection Australia (EPA)
, as well as another $51.5 million over four years for a new environment information agency.
Ms O'Shanassy says that's "a good investment in forming a new agency".
But the public is yet to see legislation to establish a national EPA, and the Wilderness Society's Tim Beshara says the government needs to get on with it.
"The new EPA and a data collection agency is a good start for figuring out how we do address the problems that we're facing on the nature side," he says.

"[But] I think that's a patch-up for where we should have been. I think that should have been in last year's budget and we should have been well advanced from where we're at right now to the reform agenda."
Both groups also say the government hasn't put any significant new money behind
its ambitious goal of zero extinctions

"There's nothing in this budget that is going to lead to additional species coming off the [endangered] list in the right way â€” that is not becoming extinct, but actually becoming more and more common, less and less rare," Beshara says.

"The Australian government has obligations for hundreds of species to have put in place a recovery plan and to fund that, and the backlog on writing those plans and implementing those plans and funding those plans is rising.

"So, until there is dedicated additional substantive funding put into endangered species recovery, things are going to continue to decline. It's hard not to see we're going to have more extinctions [under] the Albanese government."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there any information about the eligibility criteria for the $500 energy relief? Everywhere I read it says there will be a $500 relief for energy bills for eligible households but no information as to who is eligible. - John. Hi John. Here's the lowdown from political reporter, Jake Evans: The energy relief payment will be available to pensioners, veterans, seniors and other concession card holders, as well as recipients of Carer Allowance, Family Tax Benefit and anyone eligible for existing state and territory electricity concession schemes. However, the amount you receive will differ from state to state, as the money is jointly funded and the federal government has had to strike eight different deals with each state and territory. $500 will be offered in NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania $350 in total relief will be available in Western Australia and the territories $650 will also be available to eligible small businesses in states that have matched the relief.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Questions from you: Who is eligible for energy bill relief?

children.content: Is there any information about the eligibility criteria for the $500 energy relief? Everywhere I read it says there will be a $500 relief for energy bills for eligible households but no information as to who is eligible.
- John
Hi John. Here's the lowdown from political reporter, Jake Evans:

The energy relief payment will be available to pensioners, veterans, seniors and other concession card holders, as well as recipients of Carer Allowance, Family Tax Benefit and anyone eligible for existing state and territory electricity concession schemes.
However, the amount you receive will differ from state to state, as the money is jointly funded and the federal government has had to strike eight different deals with each state and territory.
$500 will be offered in NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania
$350 in total relief will be available in Western Australia and the territories
$650 will also be available to eligible small businesses in states that have matched the relief.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tim Callanan Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has taken a swipe at previous Liberal federal governments in his reaction to last night's federal budget. Andrews said there were positive signs in the budget for Victoria, declaring "the decade of rip off is over." "You canâ€™t fix nine years of neglect in just one budget but there are good positive signs, but weâ€™ll keep the pressure on, of course, because we want to get our fair share," he said. Mr Andrews said the health initiatives announced last night were "a good first step" in improving medical care across the country. "National Cabinet agreed earlier this year that health is the number one issue and it was very pleasing to see significant investments â€“ not everything â€“ but a big next step in last nightâ€™s federal budget. "Particularly, longer consultations, higher payments to GPs and higher rebates particularly for vulnerable people. This is all about a better primary care system." Andrews said he would discuss more moves to reform the health system at a health-only National Cabinet meeting before the end of the year. There was no money allocated last night towards the 2026 Commonwealth Games, which Victoria is hosting in regional centres, but the Premier said that doesnâ€™t mean there wonâ€™t be a federal contribution. "The Commonwealth Games is not happening next week so we do have time and we do have some optimism that the Albanese government will be a partner," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Daniel Andrews takes a shot at previous governments in budget reaction

"You canâ€™t fix nine years of neglect in just one budget but there are good positive signs, but weâ€™ll keep the pressure on, of course, because we want to get our fair share," he said.
Mr Andrews said the health initiatives announced last night were "a good first step" in improving medical care across the country.

"National Cabinet agreed earlier this year that health is the number one issue and it was very pleasing to see significant investments â€“ not everything â€“ but a big next step in last nightâ€™s federal budget.
"Particularly, longer consultations, higher payments to GPs and higher rebates particularly for vulnerable people. This is all about a better primary care system."
Andrews said he would discuss more moves to reform the health system at a health-only National Cabinet meeting before the end of the year.

There was no money allocated last night towards the 2026 Commonwealth Games, which Victoria is hosting in regional centres, but the Premier said that doesnâ€™t mean there wonâ€™t be a federal contribution.
"The Commonwealth Games is not happening next week so we do have time and we do have some optimism that the Albanese government will be a partner," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I am curious as to what happened to the free teaching degrees for high achievers that were promised at the election. My daughter did her bit is the government going to step up? - Richard. Hi Richard, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to political reporter Jake Evans who says: We still don't have details on the future of that policy or much at all of the tertiary sector, because the federal government is still reviewing the higher education sector, with a plan to introduce a "University Accord" by the end of the year. There were no new measures for universties this budget â€” but expect more to come in the future.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What happened to those free teaching degrees?

children.content: I am curious as to what happened to the free teaching degrees for high achievers that were promised at the election. My daughter did her bit is the government going to step up?
- Richard
Hi Richard, thanks for writing in.
I've put your question to
political reporter Jake Evans
who says:

We still don't have details on the future of that policy or much at all of the tertiary sector, because the federal government is still reviewing the higher education sector, with a plan to introduce a "University Accord" by the end of the year.
There were no new measures for universties this budget â€” but expect more to come in the future.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A number of cost-of-living measures announced in yesterday's budget will apply to pensioners. More than 5 million households will have up to $500 deducted from their power bills in the next financial year. This will apply to pensioners, Commonwealth Seniors Health Card holders, Family Tax Benefit A and B recipients and small business customers of electricity retailers. The government is also increasing the Medicare levy low-income thresholds for singles, families and seniors and pensioners from July 1, 2022, which means more people will be exempt from paying the Medicare levy in their 2022-23 tax returns. For medicines, the budget includes a $2.2 billion increase to access for medicines through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ChatGPT has declined to comment. But here's national technology reporter, Danny Tran: Artificial intelligence is getting a boost, with the federal government tipping in $101.2 million over the next five years to help businesses integrate AI and quantum technologies. That includes expanding the National AI Centre and its role in making sure the technology is responsible (I, Robot, anyone?) as well as setting up the Australian Centre for Quantum Growth. Misha Schubert from Science and Technology Australia says this type of investment is important: "Every time anyone enters a prompt or an instruction into ChatGPT or a generative AI tool, it is hoovering that up and building a complex profile about us. "So [it is] really important that we diligently deepen our investments in ethical and responsible use of AI and the sort of safeguards around privacy and copyright and security on generative AI tools." Simon Bush from the Australian Information Industry Association, the peak body for the information and communications technology sector, says we have a "very limited" opportunity to get this technology right. "We are competing with our trading partners, both friendly and not so friendly, in relation to areas like AI and Quantum," he says. "This funding enables smaller Australian innovative companies to access government support, to commercialise their IP and their technology, to really bring that to the market and also [retain] really smart people, so [we] don't lose them overseas. "Itâ€™s a really good down payment on securing Australiaâ€™s future."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hey ChatGPT, is there any money in the budget for artificial intelligence?

children.content: ChatGPT has declined to comment.
But here's national technology reporter, Danny Tran:
Artificial intelligence is getting a boost, with the federal government tipping in $101.2 million over the next five years to help businesses integrate AI and quantum technologies.
That includes expanding the National AI Centre and its role in making sure the technology is responsible (I, Robot, anyone?) as well as setting up the Australian Centre for Quantum Growth.
Misha Schubert from Science and Technology Australia says this type of investment is important:
"Every time anyone enters a prompt or an instruction into ChatGPT or a generative AI tool, it is hoovering that up and building a complex profile about us.

"So [it is] really important that we diligently deepen our investments in ethical and responsible use of AI and the sort of safeguards around privacy and copyright and security on generative AI tools."

Simon Bush from the Australian Information Industry Association, the peak body for the information and communications technology sector, says we have a "very limited" opportunity to get this technology right.
"We are competing with our trading partners, both friendly and not so friendly, in relation to areas like AI and Quantum," he says.

"This funding enables smaller Australian innovative companies to access government support, to commercialise their IP and their technology, to really bring that to the market and also [retain] really smart people, so [we] don't lose them overseas.
"Itâ€™s a really good down payment on securing Australiaâ€™s future."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to Julie Edwards from Jesuit Social Services. She says while the budget includes some positive investments to tackle the cost of living, the increase to the Jobseeker payment will do little to lift vulnerable people out of poverty. Julie: We know that many aspects of the cost of living are at near-record highs, including rental prices, petrol, groceries and other essentials, which makes it even less sustainable for a Jobseeker recipient to live a dignified life. We saw during the pandemic that increased payments reduced measures of poverty and housing stress, but a very modest increase of $2.80 per day will sadly make little difference to many. Our political leaders must create a fair social safety net that ensures all Jobseeker recipients can afford an adequate standard of living.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Anna Pykett and Wing Kuang Nationals leader David Littleproud has slammed the federal government for introducing a new fresh food tax for farmers to cover biosecurity costs. The federal budget announced a 10 per cent increase in agricultural levies to fund biosecurity activities and organisations, expecting it to raise $153 million over three years. Littleproud told ABC NewsRadio this was an "outrageous move". "They are going to tax farmers to pay for the biosecurity costs of their competitors to import product into this country, and that has to be passed on to the consumer," he said, adding it would not help address food price inflation. He also said regional Australians would have few benefits from Labor's cost-of-living package, stressing what was needed in regional Australia was infrastructure and new childcare places. He was also concerned that new Medicare boosts would lead to the closure of regional pharmacies, meaning regional Australians might face more accessibility issues in the future. "We feel like the forgotten Australians," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Nationals slams Labor for new tax on regional Australians

children.content: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Anna Pykett and Wing Kuang
Nationals leader
David Littleproud
has slammed the federal government for introducing a new fresh food tax for farmers to cover biosecurity costs.
The federal budget announced a 10 per cent increase in agricultural levies to fund biosecurity activities and organisations, expecting it to raise $153 million over three years.

props.alt: David speaks to reporters.

children.content: (ABC News: Matt Roberts)
Littleproud told ABC NewsRadio this was an "outrageous move".

"They are going to tax farmers to pay for the biosecurity costs of their competitors to import product into this country, and that has to be passed on to the consumer," he said, adding it would not help address food price inflation.
He also said regional Australians would have few benefits from Labor's cost-of-living package, stressing what was needed in regional Australia was infrastructure and new childcare places.
He was also concerned that new Medicare boosts would lead to the closure of regional pharmacies, meaning regional Australians might face more accessibility issues in the future.
"We feel like the forgotten Australians," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has criticised Labor's spending in the budget, and said it doesn't address the root cause of inflation. The budget offers a $14.6 billion cost-of-living package, including a $40 per fortnight increase to JobSeeker, which the Liberal Party hasn't yet taken a position on. "Critically, in the new initiatives that Labor has brought forward there's $2 of extra spending for every $1 of revenue. And this is the critical point: That's inflationary," he told RN this morning. "What we needed was a budget that was going to take pressure off inflation, in the process then take pressure off interest rates, and of course that helps everybody. "That's why the right budget to unite Australians, to help all Australians was a budget that was going to take those pressures away." You can listen to the Shadow Treasurer's full interview on Radio National with Patricia Karvelas here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Budget is 'unfair and inflationary', shadow treasurer says

props.alt: A mid shot of Angus Taylor.

"Critically, in the new initiatives that Labor has brought forward there's $2 of extra spending for every $1 of revenue. And this is the critical point: That's inflationary," he told RN this morning.
"What we needed was a budget that was going to take pressure off inflation, in the process then take pressure off interest rates, and of course that helps everybody.
"That's why the right budget to unite Australians, to help all Australians was a budget that was going to take those pressures away."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Jemima Burt Queensland's peak social service body says the federal government needs to do more to meet the demand for housing in Queensland. This year's budget includes a significant investment in more social housing around the country, an increase to rent assistance, and concessions for build to rent projects. But Aimee McVeigh from the Queensland Council of Social Service said research shows a significant number of Queenslanders are missing out on access to affordable housing. "Our research shows that we have 300,000 Queenslanders with unmet housing needs â€¦ If we can see that federally the government is committing to 20,000 social houses across the country it is clear that the current plan bears no relationship to the need," she said. She said despite modest rises to welfare payments, there are many Queenslanders who will continue to live in poverty. "There is in this federal budget an increase of less than $3 a day for that payment. "Clearly it isn't enough to go anywhere near lifting those almost half a million Queenslanders out of poverty," Ms McVeigh said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland housing needs more, industry figures say

children.content: By Jemima Burt
Queensland's peak social service body says the federal government needs to do more to meet the demand for housing in Queensland.
This year's budget includes a significant investment in more social housing around the country, an increase to rent assistance, and concessions for build to rent projects.
But Aimee McVeigh from the Queensland Council of Social Service said research shows a significant number of Queenslanders are missing out on access to affordable housing.

"Our research shows that we have 300,000 Queenslanders with unmet housing needs â€¦ If we can see that federally the government is committing to 20,000 social houses across the country it is clear that the current plan bears no relationship to the need," she said.

"There is in this federal budget an increase of less than $3 a day for that payment.
"Clearly it isn't enough to go anywhere near lifting those almost half a million Queenslanders out of poverty," Ms McVeigh said.
