Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people. â€œThere's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,â€ she said. However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be â€œtoughâ€. â€œWe've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,â€ she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victorian groups welcome â€˜modestâ€™ cost of living help

children.content: By Tim Callanan
Victorian social services groups have cautiously welcomed â€œmodestâ€ increases in support in the federal budget for people struggling with the cost of living crisis.
That includes an increase to the JobSeeker rate by $40 a fortnight and the governmentâ€™s energy bill relief plan.
Victorian Council of Social Service CEO Emma King said there were positive moves in the budget to help vulnerable people.

â€œThere's critical support in there for single parents, people on low incomes who need health care, and it kicked off really important investment to retrofit low-income homes to improve energy efficiency,â€ she said.
However, Ms King had one eye on the upcoming state budget, which Premier Daniel Andrews has repeatedly warned will be â€œtoughâ€.
â€œWe've got a real challenge on our hands in terms of what we've got to look forward to in looking at the Victorian budget and where those cuts might be,â€ she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Amanda McKenzie, CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary. McKenzie: This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower peopleâ€™s power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables. Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks. The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Climate Council says budget is 'a warm up lap in history's most important race'

children.content: Amanda McKenzie,
CEO of the Climate Council, says most of the measures in the budget aimed at tackling the cost-of-living are temporary.
McKenzie:

This is a missed opportunity to permanently lower peopleâ€™s power bills. To meet the climate challenge head on, Australia needs to urgently unlock the most affordable energy source available, renewables.

Sure, this Budget provides renewables assistance to 170,000 households. But when you consider the critical challenge of electrifying everything with renewable power, backed with storage, for 10.8 million households, that barely gets us off the starting blocks.

The Labor Government has demonstrated in this Budget that they want to support Australians who are struggling. Climate change makes every Australian vulnerable, so the scale of investment on climate action needs to match the task ahead of us.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By state political reporter Keane Bourke There's little in the federal budget for WA, with one of the key pledges being $11.4 million dollars to extend a defence industry training program for the state's shipbuilding sector. Extra money has also been promised for roads in Northern WA, and $16.3 million dollars for Perth to host the World Masters Games, if Australia's bid is successful. Eligible Western Australians will only receive a $350 electricity credit â€¦ below the $500 going to those along the east coast. From next year the state's GST payments will be slightly higher than forecast last year, growing to more than $9 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget for WA?

children.content: By state political reporter Keane Bourke
There's little in the federal budget for WA, with one of the key pledges being $11.4 million dollars to extend a defence industry training program for the state's shipbuilding sector.
Extra money has also been promised for roads in Northern WA, and $16.3 million dollars for Perth to host the World Masters Games, if Australia's bid is successful.
Eligible Western Australians will only receive a $350 electricity credit â€¦ below the $500 going to those along the east coast.
From next year the state's GST payments will be slightly higher than forecast last year, growing to more than $9 billion in the 2025-26 financial year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's data journalist Catherine Hanrahan. Well, it's not on a par with the $1.4 billion allocated to NSW infrastructure projects in the Labor government's first budget last October or the $3.3 billion in the Coalition's pre-election budget in March last year. This time around, NSW will get $362 million over eight years, including for safety upgrades on the Bells Line of Road and Nowra Bypass planning. There's also $3 million to look at the feasibility of an intermodal terminal in Forbes, as part of the Inland Rail program. The government has said the $120 billion in the pipeline of the Infrastructure Investment Program will be reviewed, working with the states and territories to determine priorities.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. Have heard nothing on this since 21 May. Presumably it's an inflationary measure, but still a game changer for those lagging behind the housing market  - Josh. Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter Jake Evans who says: The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year. The federal government committed in that budget to $324.6 million over four years to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government. The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Questions from you: What happened to the Help to Buy scheme?

children.content: What happened to the shared equity (help to buy) scheme that Labor took to the last election? Has this been quietly shelved or is it in progress. - Josh
Hi Josh! Thanks for writing in. I've passed on your question to political reporter
Jake Evans
who says:
The Help to Buy scheme was funded in the treasurer's first budget in October last year.
The federal government committed in that budget to
$324.6 million over four years
to establish the scheme to help people on low to moderate incomes to purchase a new or existing home with an equity contribution from the government.
The treasurer said in his budget speech last year that the scheme would assist up to 40,000 people.

They were staged for a reason. They haven't come in at the moment because we don't want to see that extra spending in an inflationary environment. That's a huge hit."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's it for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's interview on News Breakfast. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton is now taking questions from host Michael Rowland. He says the Labor government gets "a tick" for the budget being back in the black, but says it should credit the Coalition for that win. "If they had been gracious, they should acknowledge they inherited a good set of figures," Dutton says. "They obviously had a surge of income, and they have spent some of that wisely, but there's a lot of extra taxing spending that is going to be inflationary. "I worry for those families who are missing out and who are really hurting at the moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says Labor inherited 'a good set of figures'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "There's money there for the referendum, which is right because we have a referendum coming up, but also $10.5 million in mental health support for Indigenous Australians in the referendum period. What does that say about the impact that this debate is having on First Nations people?" News Breakfast host Michael Rowland asks. "Well, it is having a difficult impact," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says. "There are words that are used these days on social media and in other forms often anonymous, sometimes not frankly, some of the things that are being said in this debate are hurtful. "We're very conscious of the pressure which Indigenous Australians will be under. We know that when the vote, the postal ballot was held on marriage equality, then people in that community felt under pressure as well and we have been conscious about that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Stage three tax cuts will cost $69 billion over four years, our cost of living package comes in at $15 billion. Can you see how some people out there â€” perhaps more than some people â€” would see a massive disconnect?" Michael Rowland asks. "Well, they, of course, were legislated some time ago. They're included in the budget as they have been for some time and we have no plans to change those measures. We haven't given consideration to that," Prime Minister Anthony Albanese replies. "Do you see how some people see $69 billion for tax cuts targeting in large part wealthy Australians compared to only $15 billion for cost of living?" Rowland repeats. "Those measures begin at $45,000. If you're on $45,000, watching this program, you don't regard yourself as being wealthy," Albanese replies.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "You revealed the cost of the stage 3 tax cuts will be $69 billion over four years, four times the cost-of-living package. What is right about that picture?" News Breakfast presenter Michael Rowland asks Treasurer Jim Chalmers. "I was asked yesterday how much they'd cost and because there's an extra year of these cuts in the forward estimates, it's a bigger number than it was last name," Chalmers said. "You can see the disparity between the figures and how that would be viewed by people. "First of all, those tax cuts kick in at $45,000 and it's important that we give back some of the bracket creep in the jargon, particularly to people on low and middle incomes, but we haven't changed our position on the stage 3 tax cuts. "What we've done in the budget last night is to provide some help for people who are doing it toughest, the most vulnerable people in our community and that shows where our priorities are. "We haven't changed our position. They don't come in for more than a year now. They haven't actually been a focus of the deliberations for this budget at all."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers pressed on stage 3 tax cuts

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In case you missed it: The higher JobSeeker rate for older people, which previously applied to recipients over 60 who had received JobSeeker for 9 months or longer, will now apply for recipients over 55. It means people aged 55 to 59 will receive an additional $92.10 per fortnight above what they receive today. Treasurer Jim Chalmers says "it's a really important change." "One of the most concerning parts of the community of Australians who can't find works is over-55s and particularly women over 55 ," he told News Breakfast. "The advice that we receive from the expert committees we set up is that this is a big and growing challenge for us. It is harder and harder, particularly for women over 55, to get back into work. Big increases in homelessness and the like and we've tried to provide extra help there."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers explains reason for changing JobSeeker age threshold

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's the question that's just been posed to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The JobSeeker base rate is increasing to $40 a fortnight, which breaks down to an extra $2.85 a day. "We've tried to do as much as we can without blowing the budget and adding substantially to inflationary pressures in the economy," Chalmers told News Breakfast. "I understand and respect that there will be people who say that we should do more. There will be people who say we shouldn't have done any of this. "We've done what we can and also a lot of people who are eligible for one of these payment increases in the budget would be eligible for two or more of these increases. "You need to look across the cost-of-living package."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is that JobSeeker increase the best a wealthy country can do?

"But we've got some structural challenges in the budget. We made a heap of progress on those last night. But there will be more work to do. And again, as you said before, what we've been able to do on the foundations of a much more responsible and much stronger budget is to provide help for people doing it tough at the same time as we invest in the future."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Greens leader Adam Bandt says the extra $2.85 a day for JobSeeker is "not enough to buy a loaf of bread". "Labor promised no-one would be left behind. The budget leaves millions of people behind, giving tax cuts to the politicians and billionaires while every day people on Jobseeker are left in poverty," he told ABC News Breakfast. Bandt added that "5.5 million renters get absolutely nothing out of this budget". "Those lucky to get rent assistance might get a dollar a day. Rents in capital cities have been growing 10 times faster than that. "Labor doesn't understand how severe the rental and housing crisis is. People are sleeping in tents and cars. People are spending 60 per cent of their income on rents."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bandt says extra JobSeeker money 'not enough to buy a loaf of bread'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business Council of Australia CEO Jennifer Westacott says a budget surplus "gives confidence to markets and resilience in the future", but there were missed opportunities on multiple fronts. "The issue is it is a missed opportunity to tackle productivity and investment which will give you stronger budgets and a more sustainable surplus in the longer term," she told ABC News Breakfast. She aded there was another missed opportunity to tackle the structural deficit. "Business did all the heavy lifting last night and there is nothing to drive our investment against the backdrop of other countries who are pushing hard into this. "The hard work is fixing and reforming government services. By that, not cost cutting but going to digital services, getting improved outcomes for people, making sure we slow the rate of growth in these services, that they are efficient and effective for people and fix all of the issues in our federation."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Thomas Oriti, Lara Corrigan and Wing Kuang Independent MP Allegra Spender said while the latest federal budget is "a pretty positive budget for climate", she believed it could have gone further. Spender also told ABC NewsRadio that she didn't think the additional $2.4 billion Petroleum Rent Resources Tax (PRRT), which is subjected to gas and oil companies, was "enough". "I think the PRRT reforms were a missed opportunity," she said. "Australia is unique in our resources and we need to make sure that the Australian taxpayers get the benefit from that." Spender also thought the household electrification incentives, which was to help Australians to move away from relying on gas, was "just a first step" to help reduce emissions and cost of living. "I think we need to go further, particularly in terms of giving households the tools and information to make some of this transition," she said. "Because it's not only money, it's also a tricky transition sometimes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Independent MP says the budget could have 'gone further' on climate

"Because it's not only money, it's also a tricky transition sometimes."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is there any support for Long COVID management in the budget? - Bluey. Hi Bluey ðŸ‘€ Thanks for writing in. I've put your question to political reporter Jake Evan s who says: There is no new money for long COVID management in this budget. However the federal government has committed $50 million for further research on long COVID to be paid through the Medical Research Future Fund. A parliamentary committee inquiry into long COVID and repeat infections was released just at the end of last month, which included recommendations for long COVID clinics to be established in some public hospitals, more support and education. The government is developing its national plan on long COVID which it says will consider the findings of that committee's inquiry, so we may see more on this in the future.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A number of cost-of-living measures announced in yesterday's budget will apply to pensioners. More than 5 million households will have up to $500 deducted from their power bills in the next financial year. This will apply to pensioners, Commonwealth Seniors Health Card holders, Family Tax Benefit A and B recipients and small business customers of electricity retailers. The government is also increasing the Medicare levy low-income thresholds for singles, families and seniors and pensioners from July 1, 2022, which means more people will be exempt from paying the Medicare levy in their 2022-23 tax returns. For medicines, the budget includes a $2.2 billion increase to access for medicines through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's in the budget for pensioners?

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Bubs Australia sacks its CEO and co-founder Kristy Carr
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Infant formula maker Bubs Australia has sacked its chief executive and co-founder Kristy Carr "with immediate effect". In a statement, the company said it was due to "failure to comply with reasonable Board directions". Bubs said it had also fired its former executive chairman Dennis Lin. This is the reason the company provided for this extraordinary move: â€œNoting the recent deterioration in Bubsâ€™ financial performance over the half year, the non-executive directors considered the time was right for a change in leadership and to change the governance framework of the company to ensure that it aligns with ASX corporate governance principles and best practice." Sacking coincides with poor financial performance What's also extaordinary is that the Bubs board of directors did not bother to hide their negativity towards their co-founder and former chairman. Normally, when a top executive is forced to quit, the business would claim they "resigned" due to health problems, or a desire to "spend more time with their family". Last year, Bubs' share price surged when the United States was experiencing an extreme shortage of baby formula. The company exported large quantities of its product to the US, and was personally thanked by President Joe Biden at a virtual roundtable of infant formula manufacturers from across the world. But since the year began, its share price has collapsed by 50%. In February, Bubs Australia reported a half-year loss of $44 million. (It was a huge downgrade compared to the $702,000 half-year loss it announced the year before). The company announced Katrina Rathie as its new chairwoman last month, while Richard Paine will act as interim CEO until a permanent replacement is found.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Risk of "possibly two more" rate rises in the coming months: economist
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Economist David Bassanese of Betashares says the "unambiguously expansionary" budget will fuel pressure for the Reserve Bank of Australia to lift rates - as it continues it's fight against inflation. With growth domestic product (GDP) - the value of all goods and services produced in a given period - set to lift about 1.5% over the next two years, he says that means... "This adds to the risk that the RBA will feel the need to raise interest rates at least once and possibly twice more in the coming months". If that comes to pass, the around one-third of Australians who are currently paying off a mortgage would be hit with higher repayments. Despite a review of the RBA calling on the central bank to give equal priority to the concepts of full employment and steady inflation between 2-3%, the bank's recent decisions have confirmed it is on a mission to lower inflation at the cost of higher unemployment. Mr Bassanese praises the budget... "The Budget is admirable in that most of the extra budget bounty from a resilient economy and higher export commodity prices is being saved rather than spent (unlike, say, during the commodity boom under then Treasurer Peter Costello). Itâ€™s also hard to argue over the areas in which money has been spent â€“ mainly helping the least well off in the community" But says it should have gone harder. "(It) again makes no real effort to tighten the budget to support monetary policy in helping to rein in inflation and tackle Australiaâ€™s now ingrained structural budget deficit. The disappointment is not that the Government has attempted to support some of the less well-off in the community, but rather that greater effort was not made at a still relatively early stage in the electoral cycle to introduce tougher measures elsewhere in the economy."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Multinationals to pay a minimum 15% tax in budget hit
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Crack out the world's smallest violin to play a sad song for multinational corporations that have boosted their profit by billions through shifting it around the world ... and might not be able to do so as easily in future. My colleague, Nassim Khadem, has covered this issue for years â€” check out her explainer at the bottom of this post. The key issue is some multinational companies shift profits from countries with higher corporate tax rates like Australia (25-30%) to places like Singapore (17%) or the Cayman Islands (0%). It's expensive, complicated and contentious. But legal. Change is coming Treasuries around the world have gotten wise and have slowly been working together to make it harder. (Even though, at the same time, people have been working on the opposite side and trying to get around the new laws). Liam Delahunty, partner at consulting firm RSM Australia, noted new "global minimum tax" reforms for multinationals. This is the next phase of tax reform around the world and installs a minimum tax rate of 15 per cent. "Australia is one of 135 countries and jurisdictions collaborating on global measures to tackle tax avoidance through  the OECDâ€™s BEPS two-pillar reform plan â€“ so the global minimum tax reforms are neither new nor unexpected" But what is new, Mr Delahunty said, is the speed. "There are firm start dates which donâ€™t allow for any significant transition time and also come on the back of changes to thin capitalisation rules and intangible assets â€“ both of which are due to commence from income years commencing on or after 1 July 2023, but are yet to be legislated." What this means is the 15 per cent global minimum tax for large multinational enterprises will kick in from 1 January 2024. There are only "very modest revenue projections" from the measures, so the government doesn't foresee a bounty of riches coming from it. But it may stop the money-shuffle, and see more of it land here in Australia where the profits are being made.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Latitude's data security being investigated after cyber-attack
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We have a big update on Latitude's cyberattack. Regulators across Australia and New Zealand are now investigating the financial service company's customer data retention policies and protection. Latitude was hit by a cyber-attack in March. At least 7.9 million Australian and NZ drivers licences were eventually confirmed as stolen, and 6.1 million customer records. Some of the customer data stolen was provided before 2013 â€” including some dating back to 2005. It included information from before Latitude was Latitude, and was instead an entity under GE Money. Now, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) and the New Zealand Office of the Privacy Commissioner (OPC) have commenced a joint investigation into the company's personal information handling practices. In joint statement they said: The OAIC investigation will focus on whether Latitude took reasonable steps to protect the personal information they held from misuse, interference, loss, unauthorised access, modification or disclosure. The investigation will also consider whether Latitude took reasonable steps to destroy or de-identify personal information that was no longer required. If the investigation finds serious and/or repeated interferences with privacy in contravention of Australian privacy law, then the Commissioner has the power to seek civil penalties through the Federal Court of up to $50 million for each contravention. Six entities under Latitude are being investigated. The company has a range of services, including pay-day lending, buy now pay later services with retailers, and insurance across Australia and NZ. We have contacted the company for comment. Send our journalist an email on terzon.emilia@abc.net.au if you are a Latitude customer who is worried about your data.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Markets opens with 'yeah nah' response to budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The ASX 200 has fallen in the opening minutes of trade, dropping 0.26% or 18.8 points. It's currently at 7,245.60 points. The index tracks the fortunes of the top 200 listed companies on the Australian stock market. It is not 'the economy' but it is a key indicator of how people feel about the prospects for businesses at a given moment. At this moment it's 0.26% worse than where it was when trading ended yesterday, before the federal budget was revealed in full.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What's in the budget for business owners?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The federal budget didn't offer a huge amount for business owners. One of the noteworthy incentives was an amnesty for some businesses that are behind on their taxes. So if your business tax bill was due between 31 December 2019 and 29 February 2022 and you still haven't paid it, the ATO won't fine you if you lodge your taxes by the end of this year. But that only applies to small businesses with yearly turnover of less than $10 million. The government is also offering tax rebates for investments in 'electrification' (say, if they bought heat pumps, battery storage, induction, and energy efficient fridges). You can watch my short and easy-to-understand summary here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: AAA credit rating reaffirmed after budget by ratings agency
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As a person, your credit rating is a summary of whether you're a 'good risk'. If you're not â€” say you've been late with paying your bills or defaulted on a mortgage â€” you'll pay a higher interest rates on loans to take account of the fact you're more risky (for the lender) than other people. For nations, it's similar. Ratings agencies work out if you, a company or a nation are a 'good risk'. New comments from Fitch Ratings in the wake of the 2023 Australian federal budget are broadly supportive "The return to a underlying cash surplus in the current fiscal year and clear improvement in the federal government's fiscal position over the budget's forecast horizon is supportive of Australia's 'AAA' sovereign rating," said Jeremy Zook, director, sovereigns, APAC at Fitch Ratings. "Fiscal outcomes are stronger than what we expected when we last affirmed Australia's rating with a Stable outlook in December 2022." It also says the budget won't boost inflation. "The government's decision to allow higher than expected revenue collection to flow through to improved budget outcomes by keeping spending relatively contained, points to a commitment to its fiscal strategy and is not likely to contribute to inflationary pressures in the economy. We think the budget assumptions are reasonable and commodity price assumptions remain modest compared to our forecasts. Still, downside risks persist given the weak global outlook, elevated inflation and high interest rates Mr Zook does see "structural budget pressures" over the medium-term and warns that risks to the rating could build with spending demands "particularly the NDIS".

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What does this mean for the years ahead?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We can get very caught up in the urgency of now as we assess who's 'won' and 'lost' in the federal budget. My colleague Gareth Hutchens has examined the broader themes of the budget, and what it means for the years and decades ahead. Check it out.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US debt ceiling debate weighs on Wall Street
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Wall Street has posted moderate losses, and the negative sentiment is likely to weigh on Australian markets this morning. Investors traded more cautiously ahead of a meeting between US President Joe Biden, Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday (local time), to discuss the debt ceiling stand-off. The Dow Jones, S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell by 0.2%, 0.5% and 0.6%, respectively. Markets are waiting to hear the outcome of a meeting on Tuesday (local time) between US President Joe Biden, Worries of a potential government default loom over Washington as early as June 1, if Congress does not act to resolve the deadlock. The Democratic president is calling on lawmakers to raise the federal government's self-imposed borrowing limit without conditions. But the Republican House speaker, Mr McCarthy, has said his chamber will not approve any deal that does not cut spending to address a growing budget deficit. Past debt ceiling fights have typically ended with a hastily arranged agreement in the final hours of negotiations, thus avoiding a default. In 2011, the scramble prompted a downgrade of the country's top-notch credit rating. Veterans of that battle warn the current situation is even riskier because political divides have widened. Economists warn a lengthy default could send the US economy into a deep recession with soaring unemployment, while destabilising the global financial system that's built on US bonds.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Full budget wrap in The Business
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Catch up on last night's comprehensive wrap of the federal budget with a special extended edition of The Business. Small business owners, Finance Minister Katy Gallagher and our panel of experts pick apart the highlights and key themes revealed in the budget documents.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Budget repair?  "Missed opportunity" says former Treasury official
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A small and extremely rare surplus (spending less money than we make) has been banked by the federal government in its budget. But a former Treasury official says the Treasurer has avoided what was an opportunity to pay down our debt â€” set to top $1 trillion â€” as we pay more on interest payments for it. Hear more about it from my colleague Peter Ryan here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Inflation still hot: Will the budget help or hinder?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The increase in the cost of living from the 'inflation' in the price of key things â€” food, fuel and housing â€” has made life tougher for people. That's because wages and welfare payments aren't rising as fast, mean a cut to 'real wages' as people's purchasing power falls. With inflation currently at 7% for the year, will the budget make it better or worse? My colleague Stephanie Chalmers has been looking into it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Business benefits in budget
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers didn't talk a lot about business in his budget speech, instead focussing on household cost-of-living pressures. The elements that will have an impact are around Australia's role in the zero emissions economy of the future: renewable energy and the transition away from fossil fuels.

liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hi team, I'll be taking you through the morning as the market digests last night's Federal Budget and all of Jim's decisions. Stay tuned for news and developments through the day.

If the investigation finds serious and/or repeated interferences with privacy in contravention of Australian privacy law, then the Commissioner has the power to seek civil penalties through the Federal Court of up to $50 million for each contravention.
Six entities under Latitude are being investigated.
The company has a range of services, including pay-day lending, buy now pay later services with retailers, and insurance across Australia and NZ.
We have contacted the company for comment.
Send our journalist an email on terzon.emilia@abc.net.au if you are a Latitude customer who is worried about your data.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal budget didn't offer a huge amount for business owners. One of the noteworthy incentives was an amnesty for some businesses that are behind on their taxes. So if your business tax bill was due between 31 December 2019 and 29 February 2022 and you still haven't paid it, the ATO won't fine you if you lodge your taxes by the end of this year. But that only applies to small businesses with yearly turnover of less than $10 million. The government is also offering tax rebates for investments in 'electrification' (say, if they bought heat pumps, battery storage, induction, and energy efficient fridges). You can watch my short and easy-to-understand summary here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As a person, your credit rating is a summary of whether you're a 'good risk'. If you're not â€” say you've been late with paying your bills or defaulted on a mortgage â€” you'll pay a higher interest rates on loans to take account of the fact you're more risky (for the lender) than other people. For nations, it's similar. Ratings agencies work out if you, a company or a nation are a 'good risk'. New comments from Fitch Ratings in the wake of the 2023 Australian federal budget are broadly supportive "The return to a underlying cash surplus in the current fiscal year and clear improvement in the federal government's fiscal position over the budget's forecast horizon is supportive of Australia's 'AAA' sovereign rating," said Jeremy Zook, director, sovereigns, APAC at Fitch Ratings. "Fiscal outcomes are stronger than what we expected when we last affirmed Australia's rating with a Stable outlook in December 2022." It also says the budget won't boost inflation. "The government's decision to allow higher than expected revenue collection to flow through to improved budget outcomes by keeping spending relatively contained, points to a commitment to its fiscal strategy and is not likely to contribute to inflationary pressures in the economy. We think the budget assumptions are reasonable and commodity price assumptions remain modest compared to our forecasts. Still, downside risks persist given the weak global outlook, elevated inflation and high interest rates Mr Zook does see "structural budget pressures" over the medium-term and warns that risks to the rating could build with spending demands "particularly the NDIS".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AAA credit rating reaffirmed after budget by ratings agency

For nations, it's similar.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wall Street has posted moderate losses, and the negative sentiment is likely to weigh on Australian markets this morning. Investors traded more cautiously ahead of a meeting between US President Joe Biden, Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday (local time), to discuss the debt ceiling stand-off. The Dow Jones, S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell by 0.2%, 0.5% and 0.6%, respectively. Markets are waiting to hear the outcome of a meeting on Tuesday (local time) between US President Joe Biden, Worries of a potential government default loom over Washington as early as June 1, if Congress does not act to resolve the deadlock. The Democratic president is calling on lawmakers to raise the federal government's self-imposed borrowing limit without conditions. But the Republican House speaker, Mr McCarthy, has said his chamber will not approve any deal that does not cut spending to address a growing budget deficit. Past debt ceiling fights have typically ended with a hastily arranged agreement in the final hours of negotiations, thus avoiding a default. In 2011, the scramble prompted a downgrade of the country's top-notch credit rating. Veterans of that battle warn the current situation is even riskier because political divides have widened. Economists warn a lengthy default could send the US economy into a deep recession with soaring unemployment, while destabilising the global financial system that's built on US bonds.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Infant formula maker Bubs Australia has sacked its chief executive and co-founder Kristy Carr "with immediate effect". In a statement, the company said it was due to "failure to comply with reasonable Board directions". Bubs said it had also fired its former executive chairman Dennis Lin. This is the reason the company provided for this extraordinary move: â€œNoting the recent deterioration in Bubsâ€™ financial performance over the half year, the non-executive directors considered the time was right for a change in leadership and to change the governance framework of the company to ensure that it aligns with ASX corporate governance principles and best practice." Sacking coincides with poor financial performance What's also extaordinary is that the Bubs board of directors did not bother to hide their negativity towards their co-founder and former chairman. Normally, when a top executive is forced to quit, the business would claim they "resigned" due to health problems, or a desire to "spend more time with their family". Last year, Bubs' share price surged when the United States was experiencing an extreme shortage of baby formula. The company exported large quantities of its product to the US, and was personally thanked by President Joe Biden at a virtual roundtable of infant formula manufacturers from across the world. But since the year began, its share price has collapsed by 50%. In February, Bubs Australia reported a half-year loss of $44 million. (It was a huge downgrade compared to the $702,000 half-year loss it announced the year before). The company announced Katrina Rathie as its new chairwoman last month, while Richard Paine will act as interim CEO until a permanent replacement is found.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We have a big update on Latitude's cyberattack. Regulators across Australia and New Zealand are now investigating the financial service company's customer data retention policies and protection. Latitude was hit by a cyber-attack in March. At least 7.9 million Australian and NZ drivers licences were eventually confirmed as stolen, and 6.1 million customer records. Some of the customer data stolen was provided before 2013 â€” including some dating back to 2005. It included information from before Latitude was Latitude, and was instead an entity under GE Money. Now, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) and the New Zealand Office of the Privacy Commissioner (OPC) have commenced a joint investigation into the company's personal information handling practices. In joint statement they said: The OAIC investigation will focus on whether Latitude took reasonable steps to protect the personal information they held from misuse, interference, loss, unauthorised access, modification or disclosure. The investigation will also consider whether Latitude took reasonable steps to destroy or de-identify personal information that was no longer required. If the investigation finds serious and/or repeated interferences with privacy in contravention of Australian privacy law, then the Commissioner has the power to seek civil penalties through the Federal Court of up to $50 million for each contravention. Six entities under Latitude are being investigated. The company has a range of services, including pay-day lending, buy now pay later services with retailers, and insurance across Australia and NZ. We have contacted the company for comment. Send our journalist an email on terzon.emilia@abc.net.au if you are a Latitude customer who is worried about your data.
